text: I am obsessed with this idea now that
there's this thing called constrained
creativity and that is what everybody
who is creative does not just scientists
science is incredibly interesting
version of a constrained creativity and
all the great artists that I know have
imposed intense constraints under work
they you know like a great example is
what's-his-name that the light guy but
light guy James Terrell he he only works
with a light as his medium I mean what
an insanely intense constraint to put on
himself
so much so that he tries to remove the
room he removes a point of focus he
removes an object an image all he wants
is the light and and his work is
unbelievably transcendent because of the
severity of his constraint and I think
that this is something that my friend
Pedro Ferrara who's in an event right
now I think somewhere in the world
science mr. Hall is the one who used
that phrase from his first time
constrained creativity when we were
postdocs at Berkeley he's an
astrophysicist and it was just like you
know were just having words to lay on it
was it was like a revelation there's
something paralyzing about a lack of
constraint somebody says to you can you
can write a book about any I'd rather
someone say your next book has to be
about that building across the street or
that crate of peaches I don't care and
that would to me would be this amazing
creative challenge - Terry Gross debut
though give me something straight but I
think it fosters creativity absolutely
you
